one_reviews_text:
This game is one that seemingly always comes out when friends or family comes around for a night. I know that I can put anyone I know into this one and nausea is almost entirely non-existent. There's no need to teach people what buttons to push, nor how to play. It's self explanatory and allows people to play at literally whatever pace they feel comfortable, while making them feel like an action star. It's kids friendly (low violence, no blood, and easy to understand.)

That said, I don't mind it so much because I'm generally okay with buying it again if the game is good enough, as I like to support quality developers. I'd you're like me though, I'm sure you won't be perturbed by picking up the other version on a sale if you want. These devs deserve your support, so don't feel bad about it.

review_title: It's awesome! Absolute must play for VR.

The scenarios it puts you in are crazy, the weapons are all extremely powerful, and each hit packs a punch. review_title: Amazing Game, But Easy to Cheese
one_reviews_text:
At first, I absolutely loved Superhot. And still do. The level of immersion is amazing. There were numerous times where I felt like I could lean on cover in the game only to remember that piece of cover didn’t exist in the real world. 

And no game so far makes you feel more like you are in the Matrix than Superhot. 

I thought the campaign went for a good length, and there are some decent post-game options for continuing to play. 

My only main criticism is that I felt like I broke the game and/or cheated and/or cheesed the game toward later levels. Since time only moves when you move, you’re free to look around and dodge bullets for virtually eternity if you wanted. At a point, I learned it was easiest to play the game safe and slow, which is far less exhilarating. 

Nevertheless, Superhot was a blast and is second only to beat saber as not only a must buy for VR but also the perfect game to introduce people to VR. I can only hope for a sequel or DLC now.
Took some getting used too, challenging yet rewarding, definitely makes me break a sweat!! Worth checking out!

review_title: Great VR Intro that lacks depth
one_reviews_text: The heart of this game is it time mechanic.  This is a great idea that is absolutely neutered in the level design.  The almost 100% static positioning (room scale recognition allows minute position changes) and the lightning quick game rounds (each level of the ENTIRE game) ruin an otherwise great experience.  By the time you are having fun bouncing bottles off of enemies and dodging bullets the round is over.   If you just got your VR and are looking for something to jump  into this game is great.  If you've had your VR for a bit of time (like me) you will have more fun fighting in GORN and more fun shooting in Pavlov or Onward.  The game feels like a demo.  I really can't stress enough that you are entirely static when playing and each "level" is a very short (sometimes 10 seconds) affair.  If they opened this game up to allow character movement and lengethed the play in each level this could be something really cool.  As it stands nobody really wants to play an "on-the-rails" game like this in their VR.  The game is a tease that is fun, but still a tease.  I don't recommend buying for anyone but a VR noobie as it gets old real quick.

The concept for this game is really amazing. Unlike the other VR games available right now, this game has a bit more content and the difficulty really scales with each level. The other modes that appear once you beat the game are also quite fun.

If you've played the original, then I think there's a chance you'll be let down by the VR version. It is a completely new game built for VR. A change I was disappointed in is the lack of free movement; sure you can move around your roomscale environment, but you are auto transported to new spots which I found really hurt the experience. Given you move in slow motion, I figured thumbstick/free-locomotion would actually work pretty well in this game. Unfortunately, we don't get to find out. 

Stand in one spot, pull off a handful of moves, then get whisked away to the next scenario. Normally you play a block of about 5 scenarios before you "checkpoint". Fail on the 5th, start back on the 1st. It can get repetitive. And if you miss a ranged enemy and have no bullets/items nearby, you have to move your hands or make strange, extraneous movements to speed time along until he gets into melee range. And miss you can, as thrown objects don't seem to follow any sort of repeatable trajectories. Take your time on your aim and throw lightly to help improve your chances of repeatable throws. In what feels like a patchwork solution to the "distant-enemies-but-no-ammo" problem, a bit later on in the game you get some glitch-force ability which can explode enemies every 3 in-game seconds which, in execution, ends up feeling less like skill & more like a cheat. 

If all goes right, you can feel kinda cool like in the original. Though unlike the original, it is easier to miss and a bit harder to gracefully recover when you do. And since you can't move outside your Guardian-bubble, once the flow breaks, the feeling of "cool" breaks along with it. In the end, it feels like a fairly disjointed experience and a bit meh overall. I don't find it worth the price-tag and it ultimately feels like an average VR experience to me. But I am quite clearly in the minority, just wanted people to take a minute to look into it a bit harder and see if it is truly for them.

review_title: Great game... if you have the space.
one_reviews_text: So far, I get why people love Superhot so much. It's super fun and you get to feel like a cool, Matrix-y superhero. It's a great concept executed well and, though I didn't play the browser version, I have to imagine this is 1000x better than that. I really can't recommend this game enough. THE ONLY CAVEAT is that you definitely need a decent-sized room to play. There are a number of games that warn you that you'll need "1.5x2m of play area" or whatever and I've been able to play them without issue. Superhot, on the other hand, has you moving around enough that, despite starting in the middle of my play space, I've so far punched a lamp, a box fan, my chair, my bookshelf, and -- if a whiteboard I moved aside hadn't caught the punch -- would've put my hand through a mirrored closet door. Unlike with, say, Arizona Sunshine (which gives the same warning), Superhot won't allow you to stay in the center of your play area. To pick up or catch certain guns, catch certain objects, punch certain attackers, or grab certain throwable objects, you'll need to move around quite a bit. Be warned. Other than that, though, great game. Well worth the cost and potential hand injury/broken stuff. Plus, if you film you punching a lamp, you'll prob get a ton of hits on YouTube.

review_title: Matrix + Edge of Tomorrow = SuperHot VR

There are so many options to clear the room its up to your imagination. However, when you die - and you will alot - you'll go back in time to the beginning of the scene and start over. Just like Tom Cruise in Edge of Tomorrow. If there is any VR game you should buy now - THIS IS IT.

If you love dodging bullets, moving fast while not getting shot and feeling like you have entered a battle in the matrix - this game is for you. So much fun, can't stop playing. Really hope for more levels.

review_title: Novel game mechanic well-suited to VR
one_reviews_text:
The novel time-advancement game mechanic suits VR quite well, especially with 6 DoF controllers (e.g. Touch).

I also played the non-VR version and while it was also enjoyable, the immersion plus intuitive controls within VR enhanced gameplay.

I love the sparse visual aesthetic; it is also especially well-suited to head-mounted displays of 2016, which have low angular resolution.

The game duration is commensurate with the longevity of the game mechanic; the novelty ran out just as I was finishing the game.

I'd love to see more variations and combinations, and more of a puzzle-solving aspect.  Portal showed that even with a small number of unique game mechanics, you can achieve diversity through combinations.

Do you like puzzle games? Do you like action games? Do you have a pulse? If yes to any of these three then SUPERHOT VR is one of must own touch titles. The touch controls are intuitive and fluid with the game (with the exception of throwing objects).  The VR version has been distilled from the traditional PC version and is definitely refined since its initial release. Happy to support a developer that innovates in VR.  One suggestion to the developers would be to release a level editor  and option to share/play user created levels. 
10/10 Doctors recommended.

review_title: Makes me want to play regular SUPERHOT
one_reviews_text:
I'm not gonna go out of my way to sing this game's praises, instead, I'm gonna focus on the things that stood out to me. Unfortunately, all of them were negative. Maybe it's because I played and thoroughly enjoyed the original SUPERHOT, but I feel the game came very close and just barely missed the mark of the experience I was hyped for when I heard the words "SUPERHOT VR". My biggest gripe is that there's no HOTswitching. This mechanic was absolutely one of the things I was most excited about, and I considered it to be an excellent and novel form of locomotion for VR, sadly, it has been replaced by the ability to blow up enemies by pointing your fists at them. I understand why this was added: it was in order to prevent stalemates in the game when the player ran out of weapons with enemies that either would not or could not come closer. That said, I would much rather let myself die to an enemy bullet every once in a while when I ran out, than just drop HOTswitching entirely. And, I mean, it's not like HOTswitching couldn't take on that role, considering it kills the previous body. Second is the lack of replay value, the original SUPERHOT had a series of excellent challenges that seem relatively simple to implement, along with an endless mode where you fought off waves of enemies. This, paired with the inclusion of HOTswitching, would've made an *excellent* game that I would be thrilled to come back to again and again. Sadly, once you've completed the experience, your only reward is a level select. I beat the game in one sitting (or standing, rather), so now all that's left for me is to go through those same motions with no extra challenges. I would've even just appreciated a hard mode or something.

I sincerely hope future updates and DLC add more than just levels, because as it stands, this really just makes me want to play regular old SUPERHOT. I do recommend the game, it's worth the price *for a VR game*, but by regular PC game standards, it's severely lacking.

First of all, this game is extremely short. It only took me a little over an hour to complete, all in one sitting. There are no alternative modes or challenges or collectables, so you'll have to make up your own reasons to replay it. As such, the price is rather steep for what you get.
The levels seem to build up to something big, but it ends before we get there. A few concepts are teased in some levels, like in-level obstactles that you have to duck under, or moving doors, but these are used once and thrown away.
The game is fun and feels good when things go well, but it's often frustrating when they don't. Use up all of your weapons without killing every enemy and you'll have to wait until one of them decides to come into melee range... eventually. The game's main mechanic-- that time only passes when you are moving-- goes out the window any time you grab something or fire a gun. Doing either causes time to pass at full speed for a moment, meaning the enemies have a chance to fire at you and any bullets that were already in flight will near-instantly reach you. This feels out-of-place and usually leads to cheap deaths.
As-is, it's hard to recommend. That could change if there are (free) content updates in the future.

review_title: Way too short and too easy!
one_reviews_text:
Very short with a minimal challenge...

~1.5 hours of gameplay with limited replayability, this is because in VR you cannot move other than in your play space, and because the enemies/items are in the same place everytime there are not many ways to do things.

Considering how easy it is for the develepors to make levels for this... it is such a disgrace, and with not even a survival mode... all I can say is "Shame on you devs!"

Only a couple of parts were challenging, and only the last part of the last level was close to that frantic fast paced never relenting rush that you EXPECT from SuperHot (But I still completed this "frantic" part on my first try, I thought "Okay the game is finally picking up, I guess this was just the tutorial phase"... and then I get hit with the credits...)....

The difficulty with difficulty is because in VR you can precisely move and thus precisely control the flow of time, it is very easy to dodge and do things (unlike in the desktop version), so it would only be hard if enemies were absoloutely swarming you and you had to very carefully plan out your next few moves (I would very much like a "challenge" mode that has this).

However the developers realised it would be super easy, and so when you grab/throw an item or when you shoot it makes time run at (maybe) 3/4 speed for (maybe) 0.3 seconds, so when you perform an action get ready for the consequences. However they really could have done with a difficulty slider to alter these variables as it could definitely be more punishing.

If this was released on Steam they could atleast have enabled workshop content.... and if it was made for the Vive they could have had enemies surrounding you as they wouldn't be pandering to the people with front faced tracking only....

Basically do not expect this to be the full SuperHot experience but in VR, because it is not.

And yes, I'm playing this on the Vive (not that it matters).
